text: A Binary Tree is a specialized tree structure where each node can have a maximum of two children. These children are referred to as the left child and the right child. Unlike a general tree where a node can have any number of children, a Binary Tree restricts each node to only two children.
All leaf nodes in a Binary Tree must be at the same level.
Every node (except the root) must have at least [m/2]-1 keys and a maximum of m-1 keys.
A non-leaf node with n-1 keys must have n children.
The key values inside a node must be arranged in ascending order.
All internal nodes must have at least m/2 children.
If the root is a non-leaf node, it must have at least two children.
Array Representation: A Binary Tree can be represented using a 1-dimensional array where elements are arranged based on their positions.
Linked List Representation: A Binary Tree can also be represented using linked nodes, where each node has links to its left and right children.
Strictly Binary Tree: A binary tree in which every node has either zero or exactly two children.
Complete Binary Tree: A binary tree where every internal node has exactly two children, and all leaf nodes are at the same level.
Extended Binary Tree: A full binary tree obtained by adding dummy nodes to a binary tree, making all nodes have two children.
Threaded Binary Tree: A binary tree where all left child pointers that are NULL point to the in-order predecessor, and all right child pointers that are NULL point to the in-order successor.
